utterances: While American soldiers pulled back in Iraq, the toll is still being felt back home.
Take Salem, New Hampshire.
That's where Staff Sergeant Edmond Lo grew up and where friends and family are mourning the soldier.
He was killed while taking apart a roadside bomb in Iraq.
New Hampshire Public Radio's Sheryl Rich-Kern has this remembrance.
Edmond Lo was the second to youngest in a family of six.
His parents immigrated from Hong Kong, became U.S.
citizens and opened a computer shop.
Ed's mother is a petite woman who moves as if in a whisper, but her small, dark eyes reveal an inner strength, especially when she talks about her son.
He's the kind of man that's willing to sacrifice.
Even he knows that's a dangerous job, but he has really strong will, really determined to do what he thinks is right to do.
Ed's sister, Selma Dayak(ph), scrolls through her brother's e-mail.
These are the ones he was just (unintelligible).
Selma opens a photo of her brother in front of an Army truck.
He's standing on one foot.
It's his running-man pose.
He's being goofy.
He's always been goofy.
(Soundbite of laughter)
He used to always make us laugh.
Ed liked to make funny faces, but he also knew when to be serious.
He was a quiet leader.
There's no flash about him.
That's Chief Thomas Puzzo of Salem High's ROTC program.
People knew when he was in charge of something.
They said okay, Ed, we'll follow you, and we'll get this done.
The chief says Ed was the top student and turned down a scholarship to the Rochester Institute of Technology.
You know, I said Ed, you know, what an opportunity, and he says well, you know, I don't know, I say, kind of the Army, it's something I want to do.
Justin Engaharo(ph) was an ROTC freshman when Ed was sergeant.
Justin says Ed was the one with the book smarts, always ready to help with homework.

And even if he didn't know what you were talking about, he didn't need to know what subject you were doing, even if he's never heard of it, he'd go well, let's see what we've got in the book, and he'd crack it open and try to figure it out with you.
But Justin says that Ed was a kid at heart, like when he created puppet characters with his fingers.

We were doing the little hand (unintelligible), you know, doing little funny stuff, and we did that for like a half hour, hour in the driveway, and every car going by, like, staring at us, what are these guys, like, dancing in the driveway for?
If he's ever vindicated, it will be in court.
Things look bad for him now.

The only technical aspect of it that's left over, that he might argue, is constitutional problem with them going to his offices on the Hill - which violates separation of powers and has never been done in the history of the republic - which his lawyer might use.
And it makes you wonder why they had to do that.
They may need some other piece of evidence to actually tie him to actually doing something for the money.
But I think that whatever happens, whatever is the outcome, if he cares about his constituents in Louisiana - and boy, are they suffering - he ought to get out, right now.
If he cares about his party, he ought to get out, right now, and he ought to resign.
If he's ever vindicated, he can run again.
I think his sister's just been elected to the city council again, re-elected to city council.
So, if he has a political future, it's going to be after trial, and he's ruining things, for both the people in his district and for the - his party.
Roland Martin, I am sure that the congressman would suggest -even someone who has known him as long as Mary Frances Berry suggests -that, hey, I should be innocent until proven guilty.
And as he suggested, there are two sides to every story, and until then, I'm going to continue to walk the walk I've been doing, for some time now.
Well, he is correct, that you are innocent until proven guilty.
But the problem is, how can you effectively represent your district?
I mean, we're talking about a region that, of course, has been impacted by Hurricane Katrina.
He sits on the House Ways and Means Committee.
And so, it's not as if people really want to deal with him and be around him.
So, he's a significant liability, not just to the committee, but also to his party.
But more importantly, he's a liability to his district.
John McWhorter, we hear and have heard for years, the phrase, politics makes strange bedfellows.

When you see Dennis Hastert and Bill Frist coming to the aid William Jefferson, in this sense - them suggesting - and this is from Dennis Hastert, the House Speaker - suggesting that the raid of the Congressman's office, he believes, probably overstepped constitutional limitations on executive powers.
We heard about the separation from Mary Frances Berry just moments ago.

It is interesting to see the fodder that Republicans had used heretofore, change ways in the sense that, if you break this barrier, they, too have an open door, that they might one day see FBI agents rummaging through their offices.
Mr.
JOHN McWHORTER (Manhattan Institute Senior Fellow, Public Policy) Well, of course.
And they're extremely worried about these sorts of things because have a precedent here.
It wouldn't be surprising if we saw this kind of thing happen again, especially given that nowadays so much evidence if of the kind that would be in an office, encoded on a computer.
But the strange bedfellows question is certainly - or comment - is certainly appropriate here.
What I happen to think…
Go ahead, Mary.
Go ahead.
I happen to think that it is an important constitutional question in the history of the country.
And the founding fathers were very aware of the excesses of executive branch power, in England, and they wanted to make sure that there was separation.

So this is unprecedented, and I can see why Hastert and Frist - even if they aren't worried about anybody going into their offices, or some other Republican - would be very concerned that this precedent not be violated, that it not be overreaching.
At the same time, they're not going to defend Jefferson.

You know, Ed, what also jumps out is that Jefferson made these comments on, yesterday, but he only news conferenced a week ago, in Louisiana that… I would not be surprised if it raised the ire of prosecutors, because he had the news conference on Monday.
Then, of course, we see all of the sudden - we see an unsealing of, the partial unsealing of these documents on Saturday.
Then you have the raid.
So, you sort of had these…
Like it or not, you have a PR game that also goes on between the prosecution and the defense.
His previous attorneys were discussing a plea bargain.
He fired those attorneys, and he's moving forward.
Clearly, he's becoming very adamant in his defense.
So I wouldn't be surprised if the prosecution and the U.S.
attorney releases more information to put the public pressure on them for him to take some kind of plea.
But it's also part of the overreaching, generally, in this administration.
To have the temerity to violate 200 - over 200 years of history in American politics and our legal system.
And to send people up there to - get the warrant, go up there, and do it.
Even if they were doing it for PR reasons, it's just another example.
And that's why Hastert and Frist, I think, are concerned.
Mary, do you think…
Absolutely.
…that they were doing it just out of a kind of a wanton lack of regard for the Constitution, or do you think they could justify it in some systematic way?
Well, maybe they weren't thinking about the Constitution.
They often don't think about the Constitution, apparently, in the things that they do.
Because if they did, they wouldn't do some of them.
Let us hope.

And it may be in their eagerness, to also highlight Jefferson because he's a Democrat, and that - supposed to obscure the ethical problems that they have with, you know, the Abramoff scandal and - Do I need list all of them?
Nay(ph), and go on and on, Cunningham, as an issue for the Democrats.
But I think that that kind of careless overreaching on Constitutional questions - which characterizes this administration - is something that will haunt us long after they're gone.
And keep in mind, they say that he accepted $100,000.
Cunningham was accused and convicted of accepting $2.8 million and they never, ever conducted a raid on his office.
You know, I'm certainly not defending Jefferson because we, folks say, I have a videotape and audio tape, and that kind of evidence.
I mean, that is very damaging.
But again, I think what Hastert and Frist are looking at is, yes, precedent and whether or not that is fair.
Because, as they even understand, it could be Jefferson today.
It could be us tomorrow.
Jefferson also seems to have made it rather easy, given the sorts of things that he did.
He was rather easy to smoke out, given these very physical sorts of, you know, almost 1970s cop shows sorts of things.
Well, alleged to have done, John.
Alleged to have done.
Alleged.
Remember Alcee Hastings, who was convicted and left his seat in Congress - he wasn't convicted, he was prosecuted - and later they wanted to impeach him.
Remember that all?
He's now Congressman for Florida again.
That's what I meant when I said that if Jefferson is somehow vindicated, he can run again.
But right now, he needs to leave for the sake of his constituents, and the thing looks terrible, for the sake of the party.
